Fig. 3 Fig. 4 DRIFT spectra of NH3 on fresh (A) and pre-treated (B) Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst at 180°C for different times. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 DRIFT spectra of the NH3-SCR reaction on the sulfate Mn/TiO2 (A) and sulfate Mn-Ce/TiO2 (B). Sulfate catalyst treated in flow of NH3 (30min) followed by exposure to NO+O2 at 180°C for different times. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 optimized adsorption structures of SO2 on lewis acid sites. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 PDOS of Mn and S atom on lewis acid sites. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Optimized structures of SO2 Brønsted acid sites. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 PDOS of S, H and O atom on Brønsted acid sites. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 the proposed mechanism of sulfated CeO2 generated Brønsted acid site. Fig. 10 Table. 1 Adsorption energies, bond lengths and Mulliken charge population of SO2 on Mn/TiO2 Table. 1 Ead(SO2)(eV) SO2-Muliken S-Muliken O-Muliken R(S-Mn) RSO2(S-O) R(HO)/R(H-S) SO2 +0.001 0.465 −0.232−0.232 1.4791.479 Mn3O4/TiO2-L 4.321 −0.717 0.179 −0.287 2.235 1.56 −0.609 3.471 Mn3O4/TiO2-B 5.569 −0.335 0.249 −0.292 1.545 1.003/2.203 −0.292 1.546 DRIFT and DFT study of cerium addition on SO2 of Manganese-based Catalysts for low temperature SCR Lu Wei Suping Cui ⁎ Hongxia Guo Xiaoyu Ma Liangjing Zhang College of Materials Science and Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing 100124, PR China College of Materials Science and Engineering Beijing University of Technology Beijing 100124 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Pingleyuan 100, Chaoyang District, Beijing, 100124, PR China. Graphical abstract The mechanisms of sulfur dioxide poisoning on Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts are studied and poisoning resistance effect of cerium is revealed. Both two kinds of catalysts were deactivated to reduce NOx removal in the presence of SO2, however, the sulfur resistance performance of the Ce doping catalysts was obviously improved. From the result of DRIFT and DFT, SO2 can first adsorb on the manganese-terminal (Lewis acid sites) to form sulfates, which inhibit the adsorption of NH3 in the SCR reaction. Deactivation of Brønsted acid sites was due to the formation of bisulfite, which can react with NH4 + form NH4HSO4. For the Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts, SO2 preferentially adsorbed on Ce atom as sulfate species, alleviating the sulfation of the main active sites (Lewis acid sites and Broøsted acid site on MnOx) under the effect of SO2. Furthermore, cerium sulfate can produce new Brønsted acid site and contribute to the low-temperature SCR processes. Keywords Low temperature SCR MnOx/TiO2 SO2 DFT Drift 1 Introduction Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx with NH3 is the major technology for the removal nitrogen oxide emissions from stationary sources [1]. The commercial catalyst is mainly based on V2O5/TiO2, which is located upstream of the electrostatic precipitator due to its narrow operating temperature window of 300–500°C [2]. However, to avoid the deposition of dust on catalysts, SCR reactor is usually placed downstream of the particle controller and desulfurization device, where the temperature of flue gas is lower than the optimum temperature of catalytic reaction [3]. Therefore, there has been strong interest in developing a SCR catalyst which shows high activity in the low temperature range. Lots of researches on SCR catalytic activity concentrated on various transition metal (V, Fe, Mn, Cu, and Ni oxides) with titanium dioxide support [4,5]. Manganese oxide has been reported to contain various types of labile oxygen, which is key to conduct the catalytic reaction at low-temperature [6]. Yet, there still is certain amount of SO2 in the exhausted gas downstream of desulfurizer, which often cause an unrecoverable deactivation on SCR catalytic activity in the low temperature [7–10]. Susceptibility to sulfur poisoning extremely restrict the industrial applications of Mn/TiO2-based catalysts. For the above reason, Yang et al. [11] proposed that the sulfated CeO2 show an obvious promotion on the SCR reaction, which is quite different by other catalysts. Qi et al. [12] reported that the manganese cerium mixed-oxides prepared from citric acid method have preferable activity in the presence of SO2. Some researchers have reported that the Ce doping catalyst can improve the sulfur tolerance. Pena et al. [13] suggested that the adsorption of NH3 was the first step of SCR reaction, which determine the reaction rates between NH3 and NOx, via an Eley-Rideal mechanism or Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. Park et al. [14,15] indicated that SO2 might react with NH3 to form NH3HSO4, which is disadvantageous to complete a catalytic cycle. However, the impact of Ce component on SCR reaction, especially at low temperature under atmosphere of SO2 remain unclear. Therefore, in this work, we investigate the mechanism of the SO2 effect on adsorption of NH3 on the surface of Mn/TiO2 and the role of Ce addition in SO2 tolerance enhancement based on density functional theory (DFT) and DRIFTS method. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalytic preparation The catalysts were prepared by the co-precipitation method as we previously reported [16]. Titanium sulfate, manganese acetate was mixed under vigorous stirring at 60°C (donated as Mn/TiO2). During this process, cerium nitrate was added for the preparation of Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst. Then, carbamide solution, ammonia and hydrogen peroxide was continuously added to the mixed solution. Collected by centrifugation and washed using distilled water for two times and ethanol for two times, the precipitates slurry was dried at 100°C for 24h,and then, were calcined at 400°C for 6h in air in a tubular furnace after crushed and sieved to 40–60mesh. 2.2 Catalytic activity measurement SCR reaction was performed on a fixed-bed quartz tube reactor. The thermocouple was projected directly into the center of the reactor to measure the reaction temperature. The total flow rate was 200mLmin−1.the reactant gas condition was: 1000ppm NH3, 1000ppm NO, 200ppm SO2 5% O2 and N2 balance. The corresponding gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 40 000h−1, and the range of reaction temperature was controlled by a tubular furnace from 90°C to 300°C with a step of 30°C. The concentrations of NO, NO2, NH3, SO2 were continually monitored by an FTIR spectrometer (Bruke, Gemany). 2.3 In situ drifts study FTIR spectra were acquired using in situ DRIFT cell equipped with gas flow system. The DRIFT measurements were performed whit KBr windows coupled to BRUKE VERTER 72 spectrometers. Prior all experiments, the sample was treated at 400°C in He stream for 2h, then cooled to 180°C. All the spectra were recorded at 180°C. In DRIFT cell, the gas flow rate was 30mL/min. The background spectrum was recorded with the flowing of He and was subtracted from the sample spectrum. 2.4 Models selection and computational details According to the result of energy convergence test, we get the lowest energy repeating unit of Mn3O4 crystal cell molecular for active substances [17]. TiO2 (001) face show higher catalytic activity, so we reconstructed it by a (2×2) super cell as the carrier model. A vacuum gap of 10Å aim to avoid the interference between layer and layer. When it is cleaned under vacuum conditions, a 3-layer slab is sufficient to ensure that calculation will not too big within certain range of the accuracy requirement because of its self-driven reconstruction [18]. The bottom two layers is fixed to the bulk parameter during the optimization process. All DFT calculation were performed using modeling DMol3 from Material Studio 2016 [19]. Geometry optimizations were carried out using the exchange-correlation functional GGA-PW91 and Double-numerical quality basis set with polarization functions (DNP) without symmetry constraints [20,21]. The self-consistent field convergence energy was set to 1.0×10−5 hartree. The adsorption energy (Ead) was calculated as follows: E a d = E s u r f + E g a s − E s u r f − g a s Esurf and Egas are the energy of surface and an isolated gas molecule respectively, while Esurf-gas is the total energy of the same molecule adsorbed on surface. Note that positive value for Ead suggests a strong interaction between adsorption substrate and gas. 3 Result 3.1 Catalytic test Fig. 1 shows the influence of SO2 on NOx conversion for Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Ce/TiO2 at different temperature. When SO2 did not exist in the system, the two kinds of catalysts showed considerable activity which the NOx conversion could be approximately 90% at 180°C. After 200ppm SO2 was bubbled into the reaction system, only 45% of NOx conversion was reserved for Mn/TiO2 at 180°C, while there was approximately 75% of NOx conversion for Mn-Ce/TiO2 under the same situation. This result indicated that the presence of SO2 showed an apparent deactivation of the SCR reaction for two kinds of manganese-based catalysts, but the NOx conversion attenuation for Mn/TiO2 catalyst was greater than that for Mn-Ce/TiO2. According to Tang [22], the deactivation mechanism of SO2 on the SCR reaction could be mainly due to the sulfation of active phase. Therefore, the addition of cerium could alleviate the sulfation of active phase during the SCR reaction in the presence of SO2. 3.2 DRIFT study 3.2.1 Sulfur dioxide adsorption To investigate the existence states of sulfates to understand the interaction between sulfates and catalyst, SO2 adsorption on Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts in the presence of O2 was observed first. Fig. 2 shows the DRIFT spectra when the sample was exposed to SO2 +O2/He for different times. As shown in Fig. 2A, several bands at 1644, 1471, 1380 and 1283cm−1 were detected for SO2 adsorption on the Mn/TiO2 catalysts. The band at 1644cm−1 was assigned to absorption of HSO4 − due to the reaction of SO2 and surface hydroxyl groups [23]. According to Waqif [24], the band at 1471cm−1 could be assigned to the SO3 absorbed on surface of manganese oxides by Van der weals force. The intensity of band at 1471cm−1 increased with time suggesting that the amount of SO3 absorbed on Mn/TiO2 surface increase accordingly. The band at 1380cm−1 was attributed to asymmetric vibration of surface sulfate species with covalent SO=S [25]. After 30min of the adsorption of SO2 on the sample, the band at 1283cm−1 assigned to the stretch motion of bulk-like sulfates was detected. Overall, both physical adsorption and chemical adsorption could be formed on Mn/TiO2 catalyst after sulfuration with SO2 +O2. Fig. 2B showed the DRIFT spectra of NO adsorption on Mn-Ce/TiO2, which was far different from the spectra of Mn/TiO2. The band due to weakly adsorbed SO3 has shifted to 1510cm−1 from 1471cm−1, because peak position of DRIFT spectra for physical adsorption may have changed under different situation. The band at 1267cm−1 was much stronger than on Mn/TiO2, while the band at 1510 was weaker than on Mn/TiO2. These results indicate that the addition of Ceria might lead to more bulk-like sulfates. The sulfates might be Ce(SO4)2 because SO2 more easily adsorbed on the cerium atoms [24]. 3.2.2 NH3 adsorption fresh catalysts and catalysts pretreated by SO2 In order to simulate the sulfuration process of Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts, the catalyst was first treated by 500ppm of SO2 and 3% of O2 for 30min followed by He purging for 30min. The NH3 adsorption on pre-treated Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts was compared with that of fresh sample to investigate the influence of sulfation on NH3 adsorption. Fig. 3 A–B shows in situ DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption on Mn/TiO2 and pre-treated Mn/TiO2 at 180°C. After the adsorption of NH3 over Mn/TiO2, the characteristic vibration peaks at 3362, 3273, 1681, 1609, 1475cm−1 were detected. The band at 3362 was assigned to asymmetric stretching of NH3 coordinated to Lewis acid sites, while the band at 3273cm−1 was attributed to symmetric stretching of NH3 bound to Lewis acid sites [26]. The band at 1681 and 1475cm−1 was attributed to ionic NH4 + bound to Brønsted acid sites [27], and the stronger peak at 1609cm−1 were attributed to the formation of coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid sites [28].Therefore, there are two NH3 adsorption methods for this catalysts, coordinated NH3 formed on the manganese (Lewis acid sites) and NH4 + formed on the oxygen surface groups (Brønsted acid sites). As compared with Fig. 3B the introduction of NH3 onto pre-treated Mn/TiO2, the initial peak at 3273cm−1 due to Lewis acid sites disappeared and the bands at 1681 and 1475cm−1 assigned to Brønsted acid sites were sharply weakened. This implied that the formed sulfate species on Mn/TiO2 surface could sharply weaken the Lewis and Bronsted activity of catalyst. The decrease both of Lewis and Bronsted acidity after SO2 adsorption may affect SCR activity for Mn/TiO2 catalyst at low temperature range [29]. After the adsorption of NH3 at 180°C on fresh Mn-Ce/TiO2, the DRIFT spectra was similar to that of fresh Mn/TiO2. The bands assigned to coordinated ammonia bound to the Lewis acid sites (3376, 3261, 1610cm−1) and ionic ammonium bound to the Brønsted acid sites (1678, 1475cm−1) were also be found (shown in Fig. 4 A). But, the Lewis and Bronsted acidity of the pre-treated Mn-Ce/TiO2 was quite different from that of the pre-treated Mn/TiO2. As shown in Fig. 4B, the band corresponding to adsorbed NH3 species on Lewis acid sites (at 3271cm−1) still existed on the pre-treated Mn-Ce/TiO2 surface [26], and the intensity of the bands due to NH4 + on Brønsted acid sites (1683, 1461cm−1) appeared to increase compared to the adsorption of NH3 on fresh Mn-Ce/TiO2 [27]. These results suggest that the catalyst surface by Ce doping not only preserves Lewis acidity but also produces new Brønsted acid sites, which possibly related to SO2 adsorbed mainly on CeO2 restrain the sulfation of Lewis acid sites and create a number of new Brønsted acid sites. 3.2.3 .SCR reaction on sulfate Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Ce/TiO2 The sulfated catalysts Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Ce/TiO2 were first purge with NH3 (1000ppm) for 30min followed by He purging. When NO (1000ppm)+O2 (5%) were pumped in, the DRIFT spectra were recorded as a function of time. As shown in Fig. 5 A, after the adsorption of NH3, Mn/TiO2 was mainly covered by NH3 (3369, 1609cm−1) and NH4 + (1681, 1475cm−1). After NO+O2 passed over the catalysts, the bands corresponding to coordinated NH3 rapidly diminished (at 1615cm−1 Fig. 5A NO+O2 10–20min). It suggested that the reaction may take place between the coordinated NH3 and gas-phase NO. However, the band attributed to NH3 species on Lewis acid sites (at 1615cm−1) after introduced NO+O2 for 30min was stronger than first twenty minutes of passing NO. It could be proposed that the amount of it reacted with gas-phase NO was fewer actually due to most of coordinated NH3 has reacted with sulfate species in the sulfuration process of Mn/TiO2. Thus, the band at 1615cm−1 could be assigned Bridge nitrate due to unreacted NO absorbed on surface of catalyst [30]. According to the analyses above (Fig. 2A, Fig. 3B), the Brønsted acid sites may be associated with the SO3 species and surface sulfate, which cause the decrease of its activity. Consequently, the negative band at 1718 and 1464cm−1 was due to the displacement of the SO3 species and sulfate by NO on the surface, because both of SO2 and NO are acidic gases, resulting absorbing competitively on the same active sites on a catalyst’ surface. Therefore, the SCR reaction could only take place between a small number of NH3 bound to Lewis acid sites and gas NO. From the DRIFT study above (Fig. 4B), it was known that NH3 could absorb on sulfate Mn-Ce/TiO2 strongly, resulting in coordinated ammonia bound to the Lewis acid sites and ionic ammonium bound to the Brønsted acid sites, After NO+O2 passed over the catalysts, all kinds of absorbed NH3 (Lewis acid sites at 3367, 3273, 1609cm−1 Brønsted acid sites at 1683, 1465cm−1) have quickly vanished, and the band at 3672cm−1 assigned to water has been detected, as shown in Fig. 5B. According to the study of Kylhammar [31], Ceria can act as a SO2 trap inhibits the sulfation of MnOx in the manner of creating sulfate. As we mentioned above, introduction of Ce could preserve Lewis acidity and normally produces new Brønsted acid sites. These results indicated that both of coordinated NH3 and NH4 + have contributed to the SCR reaction under the situation of sulfur poisoning. One reaction pathway took place between the coordinated NH3 and gas-phase NO, the other pathway carried out between NH4 + and NO2 [32]. This is one of the reasons that Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts has better SO2 tolerance than Mn/TiO2. 3.3 DFT study To further study the change of Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites acidity after SO2 purging, we established the model of Mn3O4/TiO2. Parameters of adsorption energy, bond lengths and density of states, as the three aspects of data have been analyzed. The adsorption energies, Mulliken charge and bond lengths population of SO2 on two kinds of acid sites are shown in Table 1 . The obtained geometries for SO2 molecule adsorbed on the surface of Lewis acid sites over Mn3O4/TiO2 model was shown in Fig. 6 . SO2 molecule is inclined to adsorb above the Mn atoms on Lewis acid sites with its sulfur end, the distance between S atom and Mn is 2.235Å. It also can be seen from the Mulliken charge transfers of SO2, S accepted the long pair electrons of adsorption substrate. Electronic structures of the adsorption system primarily come from the partial density of states (PDOS), which aim to understand the interaction and the nature bonding between SO2 and adsorption substrate [17]. Fig. 7 shows the partial DOS of S, Mn after adsorption, we can find that the valence band of S and Mn near Fermi level mainly consist of S 3p and Mn 3d orbital. Furthermore, S 3p orbital and Mn 3d orbital have distinct resonance peaks around −1.2, 0.2 and 1.3eV, which was more likely to appear hybridization and produce a covalent bond. The bonding strength between adsorbate and surface atoms can be analyzed by comparing the degree of overlapping between the density peaks and their position with respect the Fermi level [33]. Comparing with our previous studies [17], the degree of overlapping between the peaks of S and Mn atom is bigger than the peaks of N and Mn atom, and the Ead of SO2 (4.32eV) is a far greater than NH3 (1.38eV). These results indicate that SO2 are more capable of occupying the Lewis acid sites than NH3, which inhibit the adsorption of NH3 in the SCR reaction. We observed the same phenomenon in the DRIFT experiment. In the prior study [17], we indicated that NO was inclined to absorb on Mn-terminal, and the adsorption energy was 3.07, which was slightly less than Ead of SO2. This result verified the competitive relationships between NO and SO2 mentioned above. Sulfur dioxide adsorptions taking place on the Brønsted acid sites were shown in Fig. 8 . SO2 molecule favorably adsorbed at the H atoms within the surface hydroxyl, as indicated by the intermolecular distance of 2.203Å. Mulliken population analysis demonstrated SO2 with 0.335 negative charge after adsorption and these electrons are transferred from adsorption substrate. The adsorption energy of SO2 for Brønsted acid sites is 5.56eV, which was larger with that of Lewis acid sites. The adsorption energy is owning to strong interaction. The above results reveal that the activity of two mentioned acid sites have been influenced tremendously when the sample was exposed to SO2. The possibility of SO2 adsorption on Brønsted acid sites greater than Lewis acid sites. Fig. 9 show the PDOS related to Brønsted acid sites. The contribution of the S atom in the valence band of S-HO is mainly its 3p orbital, and the contribution of H and O to the valence band is 1s and 2p orbital. The three orbitals have obvious resonance peak near the Fermi level. This may be due to that SO2 molecule react with H atom decomposed of adsorption of water molecules to form bisulfite. Furthermore, bisulfite can react with NH4 + to form stable NH4HSO4, which may block Brønsted acid sites and result in the decline of catalytic performance. 4 Discussion As seen in the results above, we can find that SO2 mainly affect the adsorption of SO2 in the SCR reaction. When SO2 was adsorbed on the Mn/TiO2 catalyst, the major band were SO3, HSO4 − and bulk-like sulfates (Fig. 2A). NH3 could be strongly absorbed on Mn/TiO2, resulting in coordinated NH3 formed on the manganese (Lewis acid sites) and NH4 + formed on the oxygen surface groups (Brønsted acid sites) (Fig. 3A). When Mn/TiO2 was pretreated by SO2 +O2 (Fig. 3B), the coordinated NH3 and NH4 + could still form, but the intensity of these band was weaker than that shown in Fig. 3A. After NO+O2 passed over the sample (Fig. 5A), small amounts of NH3 adsorbed on the active site, which was not occupied by SO2, could react with gaseous NO. NO reduction on lewis acid sites can be approximately described as: (1) S O 2 ( a ) + O ( a ) → S O 3 (2) M n n + = O + S O 3 ( a ) → M n n + = O − S O 3 (3) M n n + = O + N H 3 → N H 2 − M n ( n − 1 ) + − O H (4) N H 2 − M n ( n − 1 ) + − O H + N O ( g ) → N 2 + H 2 O + M n ( n − 1 ) + − O H (5) M n ( n − 1 ) + − O H + 1 4 O 2 → M n n + = O + 1 4 H 2 O Reactions (2) and (3) were the adsorption of gaseous SO2 and NH3 on the surface, respectively. According to our above analysis of DFT, we can find that the SO2 can easily adsorb on Lewis acid sites, which reduce the amount of effective adsorbed NH3. This process resulted in diminishing the formation of [-NH2] which was the key step for the Lewis acid sites mechanism of NO reduction. So the reaction (2) dominated under the effect of SO2 and restrained the reaction (3–4). NO reduction on Brønsted acid sites can be approximately described as: (6) − H S O 4 + N H 4 + → [ N H 4 ] H S O 4 (7) N H 4 + ( a ) + N O 2 → [ N H 4 N O 2 ] → N 2 + H 2 O Combining DRIFT study (Fig. 3A, 5A) and PDOS related to Brønsted acid sites, we can find that bisulfite can react with NH4 + to form stable NH4HSO4, as shown in Reaction (6). NH4HSO4 can hardly decompose in the low temperature and deposits on the surface of catalyst as reaction time goes on [34]. It may lead to blockage of micro pores and decreasing of surface area for Mn/TiO2 catalyst. This process may hinder the NO reduction on Brønsted acid sites (Reaction (7)). The above two points are probably the main reason of deactivation. From the DRIFT study (Fig. 4B, Fig. 5B), it was known that Ce could preserves Lewis acidity and normally produces new Brønsted acid sites. Liu et al. [24]. proposed that sulfate species might preferentially form on Ceria dopants, lessening the sulfation of MnOx sites. Yang [11]. reported that the adsorption on sulfurate CeO2 was obviously promoted to result an apparent promotion of the Eley-Rideal mechanism. When the sulfated CeO2 was formed, there will be the electronic transfer from Ce to SO covalent double bond improving the Lewis acid site strength of Ce metal ions. As shown in Fig. 10 , when a hydroxyl radical was bonded to the Ce ions, the Lewis acid site would be transformed to the Brønsted acid site [34]. The generated Brønsted acid site adsorb gaseousNH3 and enhance the formation of NH4 +, then NH4 + reacted with NO2 to form NH4NO2, which were then decomposed to N2 and H2O, as shown in Reactions (6) and (7). 5 Conclusion Mn-Ce/TiO2 show an excellent SO2 resistance compared with that of Mn/TiO2. The activity decline of Mn/TiO2 mainly was due to the sulfation of MnOx sites and the formation of ammonium bisulfite. For the Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts, SO2 preferentially adsorbed on Ce atom as sulfate species, alleviating the sulfation of the main active sites (Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid site on MnOx) under effect of SO2. More importantly, the newly generated Brønsted acid sites, which come from the cerium sulfate, enhance the formation of NH4 + and improve the SCR reaction in the presence of SO2. coredata.dc:description: The mechanisms of sulfur dioxide poisoning on Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts are studied and poisoning resistance effect of cerium is revealed. Both two kinds of catalysts were deactivated to reduce NOx removal in the presence of SO2, however, the sulfur resistance performance of the Ce doping catalysts was obviously improved. From the result of DRIFT and DFT, SO2 can first adsorb on the manganese-terminal (Lewis acid sites) to form sulfates, which inhibit the adsorption of NH3 in the SCR reaction. Deactivation of Brønsted acid sites was due to the formation of bisulfite, which can react with NH4 + form NH4HSO4. For the Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts, SO2 preferentially adsorbed on Ce atom as sulfate species, alleviating the sulfation of the main active sites (Lewis acid sites and Broøsted acid site on MnOx) under the effect of SO2. Furthermore, cerium sulfate can produce new Brønsted acid site and contribute to the low-temperature SCR processes.
coredata.dc:title: DRIFT and DFT study of cerium addition on SO2 of Manganese-based Catalysts for low temperature SCR
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
